posts.name: Ross Hagglund
posts.cooked:
As part of getting ready for competition one of our regions (PNW) robot inspectors dropped by to walk the kids through an inspection (a lot of kids that have never done an inspection this year).  There was one question that jumped out at me as new “What safeguards do you have in place to prevent field damage with your high traction wheels?”  when I heard this I interrupted their conversation to ask for clarification. Apparently they are looking for some software control that will identify when our robot has hit an immovable object (i.e. a field element or wall) and will dampen/kill the motor output prior to field damage.

Has anyone heard if this is really going to “be a thing”?

Has anyone actually written code that does what they are asking for? (Google and I haven’t found it yet if it does exist)

Our robot uses SDS Mk4’s for a swerve drive, the code is java based derived from 2910’s common library.  Does anyone have any form of force dampening code they use to prevent field damage?

Ross Hagglund - Assistant Coach / Software Mento 2374 - Crusaderbots

posts.name: 346CADmen
posts.cooked: Answer, no or none. I have cots components that are legal for competition. If you/they are concerned about some type transmission damping, they might need clarify robot to robot contact rules.

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked:
Imo, this shouldn’t be a stop for inspection, as this is like asking “what safeguards to have to stop your robot from harming refs with your X foot arm.”

That said could make a system that checks AMP draw of your drive motors, looking for extra high draws and/or uses your IMU to check for a crash/shock but sees no motion after, tho both cases could cause false negatives.

posts.name: Harrison Drake
posts.cooked: Ask them to show you the line item on the inspection checklist.

posts.name: Nate Laverdure (he/him)
posts.cooked:
It is famously more of an issue in PNW than in other regions because they traditionally do not use hardboard underlayment under the field carpet.

You might consider re-asking Q148 from last year’s QA.

posts.name: Brian Wagg
posts.cooked:
If this happens at an actual event (inspector asking to see such features/code), ask them to show you the robot rule they are referencing. If they can’t provide one and continue to push the matter, ask to speak with the LRI.

If HQ has instructed inspectors all across FIRST to be enforcing this, teams should have been notified that R201 would be enforced/evaluated differently than in all previous years. If HQ hasn’t instructed all inspectors in FIRST to enforce R202 in this manner, the inspectors at your events have no business enforcing it like that.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: Tagging @Al_Skierkiewicz and @ChuckDickerson because this seems pretty suspect to me. There is R201, but that applies to adding things like spikes or cleats that actively dig into the carpet. There is also nothing I see in the inspection checklist ( https://firstfrc.blob.core.windows.net/frc2023/Manual/2023-inspection-checklist.pdf ) other than the call-out of R201 that should require any kind of traction limiting on you drivetrain

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Current limit your brushless drive motors.  It’s easy to do.  If an inspector asks you to do this to pass inspection and you respond with rules-lawyering instead of making some minor code changes to be in compliance, you’re being unreasonable.

When you ruin the event carpet, you lower the quality of play for everyone at the event.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Zoe Ruel
posts.cooked: I’d say a combination of current limit on drive motors and the disable button if the robot ends up driving into a wall uncontrollably and burning 4 holes in the carpet. But I haven’t put much thought into it beyond that

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: Is this really rules lawyering though? R201 specifically calls out things like studs, cleats, sandpaper, or hook and loop fasteners. It doesn’t say anything about regular rubber/plastic wheels. Asking teams to comply with rules that are not specifically stated in the rulebook is much more unreasonable imo.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

Current limit your brushless drive motors. It’s easy to do.

Right answer for the wrong reasons. Current limiting drive is important for avoiding brownouts (we stuttered hard the first time we launched a very light robot without them as the RIO commanded brownout protection), and maybe you can use it as a cop-out to get an “eager” inspector off of the matter.

But you shouldn’t have to.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.custom_user_title: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Billfred:

But you shouldn’t have to.

Why?

Does asserting your right under the rules-as-written to damage the field via incompetent coding really make the event better for you or anyone else?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Noah Eckfeldt
posts.cooked:
as someone who was at the week 1 event in the PNW as a robot inspector last year i can confirm that it was an issue because there was no hardboard under the carpet at the event. I never asked and will not ask teams that I am inspecting to have such a feature but to be aware of the fact that their modules could cause damage to the field.

ofc your mileage will vary but it is not defined by the rules and I will not uphold something that isnt in the book

posts.name: Nate Laverdure (he/him)
posts.cooked: If I was the underwriter… I would do my best to not pay out the claim for the gym floor if the event failed to put down underlayment.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
You also seem to be oversimplifying a complex physics problem with a “just put a current limit in place” statement.

Robots that are destroying the field carpet are probably not stalling their wheels in place but are likely traction limited and are in fact spinning their wheels in place thus burning said holes in carpet. How would you reliably detect the difference in the two?

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

Does asserting your right under the rules-as-written to damage the field via incompetent coding really make the event better for you or anyone else?

Is it incompetent coding, incompetent driving, too-competent driving from the opposing alliance, incompetent gear ratio choice, incompetent on-field weight, or carpet that has already been beaten within an inch of its life by others in prior matches?

Point being: Don’t put it on my programmers with so many external forces.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.custom_user_title: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.cooked: They put stuff under the carpet now, but its a big issue in PNW due to the high percentage of teams running treaded wheels. Last year at gpk and wilsonvile there were many many many holes in the carpet

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: Because asking teams at the last minute to make changes to comply with unwritten rules makes the event worse for every team. If this is an issue all over, there should be a rules update so that all teams have a fair chance at fixing the issue ahead of time. If this is an issue in just one region, which is what it sounds like, that region should bring their field up to the specs that every other region uses to prevent the issue.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Set the current limit to a value that can’t break static friction in the first place.  It’s very easy to determine such a value from either physical approximations or a simple static test routine.

This is something any team can do in about 10 minutes that improves the competition for everyone.  If the event staff asks you to do this and you refuse on the grounds of rules-lawyering, you’re being a jerk.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: marshall
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

Does asserting your right under the rules-as-written to damage the field via incompetent coding really make the event better for you or anyone else?

Let’s have some empathy… please?

Not all teams have students or mentors who can program and do this work.  They don’t deserve to be called incompetent or be passively aggressively mocked for damaging the field.

Further - we put insane limits on our drivetrain last year and STILL got called out by an FTA for “damaging the field”.  Limits that would not break traction… and yet…

I don’t understand why swerve is being called out as being this massive destructive force by inspectors or anyone.

I’ve got holes in my lab carpet that @Andrew_Schreiber can attest to were put there by NEOs on a KOP drive.  I’ve also had holes from CIM motors on a 6 wheel WCD with colsons…

If we want to set this limit then we need to set it for all teams.  If not… we need to maybe not set it…

OK, I was asked to comment so I will.  Inspectors are trained to inspect to the rules.  That is why the inspection checklist has the rule numbers clearly added to each line item.  That is also why, inspectors did not inspect for that last year when some (emphasis on “some”) robots damaged carpet.
